results.headline: In 'Say Uncle,' an Adult With an  Unhealthy Attachment to the Playground

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Say Uncle

results.summary_short: A comedy about a suspected gay pedophile is something even Mel Brooks might balk at, but "Say Uncle" would have benefited from his ability to turn bad taste into good feature.

results.headline: 'Krrish' Tells the Further Adventures of a Bollywood Superhero

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Krrish

results.summary_short: A young man with superhuman powers doubles as Krrish, a masked hero, in a Bollywood sequel that blends carefree romance, show-stopping action and sci-fi.

results.headline: In 'The Devil Wears Prada,' Meryl Streep Plays the Terror of the Fashion World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Devil Wears Prada

results.summary_short: Meryl Streep inspires both terror and a measure of awe as the imperious editor of a glossy fashion magazine in the screen version of Lauren Weisberger's best-selling novel.

results.headline: An Iraqi Boy in the Middle of a War in 'The Blood of My Brother'
results.display_title: The Blood of My Brother: A Story of Death in Iraq

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blood of My Brother: A Story of Death in Iraq

results.summary_short: From the filmmaker Andrew Berends comes another documentary about the occupation of Iraq, but this time the story is told from the Iraqi point of view.

results.headline: 'Room' Explores a Woman's Psychic War on Terrorism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Room

results.summary_short: A Texas woman flees homeland insecurity for a New York vision quest in this acute, resourceful and bracingly ambitious debut film.

results.headline: 'Who Killed the Electric Car?': Some Big Reasons the Electric Car Can't Cross the Road

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who Killed the Electric Car?

results.summary_short: Fast and furious, "Who Killed the Electric Car?" is the sad tale of yet one more attempt by a heroic group of civic-minded souls to save the browning, warming planet.

results.headline: Bulls Remain a Rough Ride in 'Rank'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rank

results.summary_short: "Rank" is as thorough an examination of the sport of bull riding as you could hope to squeeze into 90 taut, well-organized minutes.

results.headline: A Chinese-American Boy Comes of Age in 'The Motel'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Motel

results.summary_short: Michael Kang's small, perfectly observed portrait of a Chinese-American boy  captures the glum desperation of inhabiting the biological limbo of early adolescence.

results.headline: In 'Strangers With Candy,' Amy Sedaris's Jerri Blank Is Streetwise and Starting Over

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strangers with Candy

results.summary_short: Like many feature films based on small-screen, short-form comedy, "Strangers With Candy" feels more like a long, sloppy "very special" episode than a movie.

results.headline: 'Superman Returns' to Save Mankind From Its Sins

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Superman Returns

results.summary_short: Where once the Man of Steel flew up, up and away, in a leaden new film he flies down, down, down, sent from above to save mankind from its sins.

results.headline: A Love Triangle Like No Other in 'Two Drifters'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Drifters

results.summary_short: From the dexterous mind of the Portuguese filmmaker João Pedro Rodrigues comes a head trip through the landscape of desire.

results.headline: Everything Is Different, but Life Goes On Anyway, in 'The Great New Wonderful'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great New Wonderful

results.summary_short: Danny Leiner's film offers a collection of quiet, tidy vignettes that occur simultaneously in New York City a year after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

results.headline: Skateboarders' Wild  Ride in Larry Clark's  'Wassup Rockers'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wassup Rockers

results.summary_short: More than a decade after Larry Clark scandalized the movie world with "Kids," he is still pushing buttons with his lubricious insider's view of teenage life.

results.headline: In 'Waist Deep,' Daddy Love on a Rampage, With Melancholic Brio

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waist Deep

results.summary_short: "Waist Deep" is unapologetically a B movie, its narrative premise placed carefully on the borderline between the wildly implausible and the completely absurd.

results.headline: 'The Road to Guantánamo' Offers Grim Chronicles That Anger and Stir

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Road To Guantanamo

results.summary_short: "The Road to Guantánamo," based on the testimony of three British Muslims captured in Afghanistan in 2001, is a wrenching and dismaying account of cruelty and bureaucratic indifference.

results.headline: 'The Forsaken Land' Tells the Tale of Sri Lanka's Walking Wounded

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forsaken Land

results.summary_short: Some films offer up their mysteries openly; others, like this quietly affecting Sri Lankan film, keep their secrets close, revealing them gradually shot by shot, scene by scene.

results.headline: A Man-Child Who Has His World Under Control in 'Click'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Click

results.summary_short: Adam Sandler turns his careless attention to family life in this comedy about a harried white-collar father who acquires a remote control that allows him to hopscotch through time.

results.headline: Samurai Battle for Survival in 'The Hidden Blade'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hidden Blade

results.summary_short: By taking samurai-movie conventions and placing them in the harsh light of daily survival, the veteran filmmaker Yoji Yamada illuminates the twilight of an entire way of life.

results.headline: Asking the Great Questions While Lounging About Venice in 'The Garden of Earthly Delights'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Garden of Earthly Delights

results.summary_short: Lech Majewski's digital video riff on "Death in Venice" takes its name from the triptych  by Hieronymus Bosch.

results.headline: 'Leonard Cohen: I'm Your Man': A Documentary Song of Praise

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leonard Cohen I'm Your Man

results.summary_short: Lian Lunson's wonderful documentary portrait combines pieces of an extended interview with Mr. Cohen with a tribute concert at the Sydney Opera House in January 2005.
